problems.title: Max Window Sum
problems.description:
You are given an array of integers and a window size k. Your task is to find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size k. If k is greater than the array size, print 0.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and k.
Second line: n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum sum of any window of size k, or 0 if such window does not exist.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
7 3
2 5 -1 7 3 -1 2

Sample Output
11

Explanation:
The maximum sum window is [5, -1, 7] with sum 11.

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def maxWindowSum(self, arr, n, k):
        # TODO: Return maximum sum of any window of size k
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_k = input().split()
    n = int(n_k[0])
    k = int(n_k[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    print(sol.maxWindowSum(arr, n, k))

hintsList: Compute the sum of the first window of size k directly.
Slide the window by one element at a time: subtract the element leaving the window and add the new element entering it.

problems.title: Count Even Numbers in Each Window
problems.description:
Given an array of integers and a window size k, print the number of even numbers in every contiguous subarray (window) of size k. If k is greater than n, print nothing.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and k.
Second line: n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the count of even numbers for each window of size k on a single line, separated by spaces.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5 3
1 2 4 5 6

Sample Output
2 1 2

Explanation:
Windows: [1,2,4] -> 2 evens, [2,4,5] -> 2 evens, [4,5,6] -> 2 evens. (Your implementation should match the definition of even numbers in the window.)

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def countEvenInWindows(self, arr, n, k):
        # TODO: Return a list of counts of even numbers for each window of size k
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_k = input().split()
    n = int(n_k[0])
    k = int(n_k[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    res = sol.countEvenInWindows(arr, n, k)
    print(' '.join(map(str, res))) if res else print('', end='')

hintsList: Maintain the count of even numbers in the current window instead of recounting each time.
When you slide the window, update the count by checking the element leaving and the element entering the window.

problems.title: First Negative Number in Each Window
problems.description:
Given an array of integers and a window size k, for each window of size k print the first negative number in that window. If a window does not contain any negative number, print 0 for that window.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and k.
Second line: n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the first negative number for each window on a single line, separated by spaces.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
8 3
12 -1 -7 8 -15 30 16 28

Sample Output
-1 -1 -7 -15 -15 0

Explanation:
For each window of size 3, we output the first negative element if it exists, else 0.

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def firstNegativeInWindows(self, arr, n, k):
        # TODO: Return a list of first negative numbers for each window (0 if none)
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_k = input().split()
    n = int(n_k[0])
    k = int(n_k[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    res = sol.firstNegativeInWindows(arr, n, k)
    print(' '.join(map(str, res)))

hintsList: Use a queue (or list) to store indices of negative numbers in the current window.
Remove indices that move out of the window and take the front of the queue as the first negative for each window.

problems.title: Longest Unique Substring
problems.description:
Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

Input Format:
A single string s (no spaces).

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the length of the longest substring with all unique characters.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
abcabcbb

Sample Output
3

Explanation:
The longest substring without repeating characters is 'abc' with length 3.
problems.constraints:
1 <= |s| <= 100000
Characters are visible ASCII characters (no spaces).
hintsList: Use a sliding window with two pointers and an array/map to track the last seen index of each character.
When you see a repeated character inside the current window, move the left pointer just after its previous occurrence.

problems.title: Longest Subarray with Sum At Most K
problems.description:
Given an array of non-negative integers and an integer K, find the length of the longest contiguous subarray whose sum is less than or equal to K.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and K.
Second line: n space-separated non-negative integers.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum length of such subarray.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5 7
2 1 5 1 3

Sample Output
3

Explanation:
The longest subarray with sum <= 7 is [1,5,1] with length 3.

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def longestSubarrayAtMostK(self, arr, n, K):
        # TODO: Return the length of the longest subarray with sum <= K
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_K = input().split()
    n = int(n_K[0])
    K = int(n_K[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    print(sol.longestSubarrayAtMostK(arr, n, K))

hintsList: Use two pointers (sliding window) and maintain the current sum.
While the sum is greater than K, move the left pointer forward and subtract elements from the sum, updating the maximum window length when the sum is <= K.

problems.title: Smallest Subarray with Sum At Least K
problems.description:
Given an array of positive integers and an integer K, find the length of the smallest contiguous subarray whose sum is greater than or equal to K. If no such subarray exists, print 0.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and K.
Second line: n space-separated positive integers.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the minimum length of such subarray, or 0 if it does not exist.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5 7
2 3 1 2 4

Sample Output
2

Explanation:
The subarray [3,4] has sum 7 and length 2, which is minimal.

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def smallestSubarrayAtLeastK(self, arr, n, K):
        # TODO: Return the length of the smallest subarray with sum >= K (0 if none)
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_K = input().split()
    n = int(n_K[0])
    K = int(n_K[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    print(sol.smallestSubarrayAtLeastK(arr, n, K))

hintsList: Use two pointers and maintain the current sum while expanding the right end.
Whenever the sum is >= K, try shrinking from the left to minimize the window length and update the answer.

problems.title: Longest Substring with At Most K Distinct Characters
problems.description:
Given a string s and an integer K, find the length of the longest substring that contains at most K distinct characters.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: integer K.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the length of the longest valid substring.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
araaci
2

Sample Output
4

Explanation:
The longest substring with at most 2 distinct characters is 'araa' with length 4.
hintsList: Use a sliding window and a frequency map to track the count of each character.
If the number of distinct characters exceeds K, move the left pointer and decrease counts until it becomes at most K again.

problems.title: Max Consecutive Ones After Flipping At Most K Zeros
problems.description:
Given a binary array (containing only 0s and 1s) and an integer K, you are allowed to flip at most K zeros to ones. Find the maximum number of consecutive ones you can obtain in the array after at most K flips.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and K.
Second line: n space-separated integers (each 0 or 1).

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum number of consecutive ones possible.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
7 1
1 0 1 1 0 1 1

Sample Output
5

Explanation:
Flipping the zero at index 1 gives: [1,1,1,1,0,1,1] with a maximum run of 4 ones. Flipping index 4 gives [1,0,1,1,1,1,1] with a maximum run of 5 ones, which is optimal.
problems.constraints:
1 <= n <= 100000
0 <= K <= n
Each element is 0 or 1.

starterCodes.code:
class Solution:
    def maxConsecutiveOnesAfterFlips(self, arr, n, K):
        # TODO: Return the maximum number of consecutive ones after flipping at most K zeros
        pass

if __name__ == '__main__':
    n_K = input().split()
    n = int(n_K[0])
    K = int(n_K[1])
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    sol = Solution()
    print(sol.maxConsecutiveOnesAfterFlips(arr, n, K))

hintsList: Use a sliding window and keep track of how many zeros are in the current window.
If the number of zeros exceeds K, move the left pointer forward until the count of zeros is at most K again, updating the maximum window size.

problems.title: Minimum Window Substring Containing All Characters
problems.description:
Given two strings s and t, find the length of the smallest substring of s that contains all the characters of t (including duplicates). If no such substring exists, print -1.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: string t (no spaces).

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the length of the smallest window, or -1 if it does not exist.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
ADOBECODEBANC
ABC

Sample Output
4

Explanation:
The minimum window substring is 'BANC' with length 4.
hintsList: Use two frequency maps: one for t and one for the current window in s.
Expand the window to satisfy all characters, then shrink from the left while still satisfying the condition to minimize the window length.

problems.title: Count Anagram Substrings
problems.description:
Given two strings s and p, count how many substrings of s are anagrams of p.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: string p (no spaces).

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the count of substrings of s that are anagrams of p.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
forxxorfxdofr
for

Sample Output
3

Explanation:
The anagram substrings are 'for', 'orf', and 'ofr'.
hintsList: Use a frequency array for p and a sliding window frequency array for the current window in s.
Slide the window of size |p| over s, updating counts in O(1), and compare the frequency arrays to check for an anagram.

problems.title: Maximum Vowels in Substring of Length K
problems.description:
Given a string s and an integer k, return the maximum number of vowel letters in any substring of s with length k.
Vowel letters in English are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', and 'u'.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: integer k.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum number of vowels in any window of size k.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
abciiidef
3

Sample Output
3

Explanation:
The substring "iii" contains 3 vowels.
problems.constraints:
1 <= |s| <= 100000
1 <= k <= |s|
s consists of lowercase English letters.
hintsList: Use a sliding window of size k.
Count vowels in the first window, then slide one char at a time, updating the count.

problems.title: Subarray Product Less Than K
problems.description:
Given an array of positive integers and an integer k, return the number of contiguous subarrays where the product of all the elements in the subarray is strictly less than k.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and k.
Second line: n space-separated positive integers.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the count of valid subarrays.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
4 100
10 5 2 6

Sample Output
8

Explanation:
The 8 subarrays that have product less than 100 are:
[10], [5], [2], [6], [10, 5], [5, 2], [2, 6], [5, 2, 6].
Note that [10, 5, 2] has product 100, which is not strictly less than 100.
hintsList: Use a sliding window. Expand right and multiply to current product.
If product >= k, shrink from left by dividing until product < k.
For each valid window ending at right, add (right - left + 1) to the count.

problems.title: Longest Repeating Character Replacement
problems.description:
You are given a string s consisting of uppercase English characters and an integer k. You can choose any character of the string and change it to any other uppercase English character. You can perform this operation at most k times.
Return the length of the longest substring containing the same letter you can get after performing the above operations.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: integer k.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum length of such substring.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
ABAB
2

Sample Output
4

Explanation:
Replace the two 'A's with 'B's or vice versa.
problems.constraints:
1 <= |s| <= 100000
0 <= k <= |s|
s consists of uppercase English letters.
hintsList: Use a sliding window and track the frequency of the most frequent character in the current window.
The number of replacements needed is (window length - max frequency). If this > k, shrink window.

problems.title: Contains Duplicate II
problems.description:
Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return true if there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that nums[i] == nums[j] and abs(i - j) <= k.

Input Format:
First line: two integers n and k.
Second line: n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print "true" if such indices exist, otherwise "false".
problems.examples:
Sample Input
4 3
1 2 3 1

Sample Output
true

Explanation:
nums[0] == 1 and nums[3] == 1, and abs(0 - 3) = 3 <= 3.
hintsList: Use a sliding window or a hash set to store elements in the current window of size k.
If an element is already in the set, return true. If the set size exceeds k, remove the oldest element.

problems.title: Get Equal Substrings Within Budget
problems.description:
You are given two strings s and t of the same length and an integer maxCost.
You want to change s to t. Changing the i-th character of s to i-th character of t costs |s[i] - t[i]| (that is, the absolute difference between the ASCII values of the characters).
You are also given an integer maxCost.
Return the maximum length of a substring of s that can be changed to be the same as the corresponding substring of t with a cost less than or equal to maxCost.
If there is no substring from s that can be changed to its corresponding substring from t, return 0.

Input Format:
First line: string s (no spaces).
Second line: string t (no spaces).
Third line: integer maxCost.

Output Format:
Print a single integer: the maximum length of such substring.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
abcd
bcdf
3

Sample Output
3

Explanation:
Costs: |a-b|=1, |b-c|=1, |c-d|=1, |d-f|=2. Costs array: [1, 1, 1, 2].
Substrings with cost <= 3:
[1, 1, 1] sum=3, len=3.
[1, 1, 2] sum=4 > 3.
Max length is 3.
problems.constraints:
1 <= |s| <= 100000
|t| == |s|
0 <= maxCost <= 10^6
s and t consist of lowercase English letters.
hintsList: Calculate the cost for each index: abs(s[i] - t[i]).
Use a sliding window on the cost array to find the longest subarray with sum <= maxCost.
